diagrams.description: Computer architecture history began in the 1940s with ENIAC, the first electronic general-purpose computer, and the 1945 Von Neumann architecture concept introducing stored-program design. The 1950s saw transistor-based computers replace vacuum tubes. 1964 introduced IBM System/360 with compatible family architecture. The 1970s brought microprocessors (Intel 4004 in 1971, 8086 in 1978 establishing x86). The 1980s witnessed RISC architecture development and personal computer proliferation. 1993 introduced Intel Pentium with superscalar architecture. The 2000s marked multi-core processor era and 64-bit computing mainstream adoption. The 2010s advanced with mobile ARM dominance, GPU computing, and AI accelerators. The 2020s continue with quantum computing breakthroughs and neuromorphic chip development.
diagrams.mermaid_code:
timeline
    title: The History of Computer Architecture
    section: The 1940s - The Dawn of Computing
        1945: John von Neumann's "First Draft of a Report on the EDVAC"
        1947: The transistor is invented
    section: The 1950s-1960s - Mainframes
        1951: UNIVAC I, the first commercial computer
        1964: IBM System/360, the first family of compatible computers
    section: The 1970s - Microprocessors
        1971: Intel 4004, the first microprocessor
        1978: Intel 8086, the first 16-bit microprocessor
    section: The 1980s - RISC vs. CISC
        1980s: The RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer) vs. CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer) debate
        1985: The ARM architecture is introduced
    section: The 1990s - Parallelism
        1990s: Rise of parallel processing and supercomputers
    section: The 2000s - Multi-Core Processors
        2005: First dual-core processors
    section: The 2010s - Mobile and Cloud
        2010s: Rise of mobile and cloud computing
        2010s: GPUs for general purpose computing (GPGPU)
